title: William FitzGerald-de Ros, 22nd Baron de Ros
text:
William Lennox Lascelles FitzGerald-de Ros, 22nd Baron de Ros of Helmsley, <a href="Her%20Majesty%27s%20Most%20Honourable%20Privy%20Council">PC</a>, <a href="Deputy%20Lieutenant">DL</a> (1 September 1797 – 6 January 1874), was a British soldier and <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28UK%29">Conservative</a> politician. A general in the Army, he also held political office as <a href="Captain%20of%20the%20Yeomen%20of%20the%20Guard">Captain of the Yeomen of the Guard</a> in 1852 and between 1858 and 1859.
Background.
Fitzgerald-de Ros was born into an <a href="Anglo-Irish%20people">Anglo-Irish</a> aristocratic family at <a href="Thames%20Ditton">Thames Ditton</a>, <a href="Surrey">Surrey</a>, the third son of <a href="Lord%20Henry%20FitzGerald">Lord Henry FitzGerald</a>, fourth son of <a href="James%20FitzGerald%2C%201st%20Duke%20of%20Leinster">The 1st Duke of Leinster</a> and <a href="Emily%20FitzGerald%2C%20Duchess%20of%20Leinster">Lady Emily Lennox</a>. His paternal uncle was <a href="Lord%20Edward%20FitzGerald">Lord Edward FitzGerald</a>, the Irish revolutionary. His mother was <a href="Charlotte%20FitzGerald-de%20Ros%2C%2020th%20Baroness%20de%20Ros">Charlotte FitzGerald-de Ros, 20th Baroness de Ros</a>, while <a href="Henry%20FitzGerald-de%20Ros%2C%2021st%20Baron%20de%20Ros">Henry FitzGerald-de Ros, 21st Baron de Ros</a>, was his elder brother. Through his paternal grandmother he was a descendant of <a href="Charles%20II%20of%20England">King Charles II</a>.
Military career.
As a younger son, de Ros embarked upon a military career, joining the <a href="Life%20Guards%20%28British%20Army%29">Life Guards</a> as a <a href="cornet">cornet</a> on 29 March 1819. He subsequently became a <a href="lieutenant">lieutenant</a> on 24 August 1821, a <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a> on 23 October 1824, a <a href="major">major</a> on 5 June 1827 and a <a href="lieutenant-colonel">lieutenant-colonel</a> on 8 September 1831. In July 1835, de Ros and the <a href="John%20Lambton%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Durham">Earl of Durham</a> travelled to the <a href="Black%20Sea">Black Sea</a> for half a year to investigate Russian military preparations. He was appointed a <a href="Gentleman%20Usher">Gentleman Usher</a> Quarter Waiter to <a href="Queen%20Victoria">Queen Victoria</a> in 1836, but had surrendered the post by 1839, when he inherited the <a href="Baron%20de%20Ros">barony of de Ros</a> on the death of his eldest brother (a middle brother, Arthur, had predeceased them). He became a <a href="colonel">colonel</a> on 9 November 1846, and was appointed <a href="Deputy%20Lieutenant">Deputy Lieutenant</a> of the <a href="Tower%20of%20London">Tower of London</a> on 13 February 1852.
Lord de Ros served as <a href="Quartermaster-General">Quartermaster-General</a> for the British Army in Turkey during the <a href="Crimean%20War">Crimean War</a> between April and July 1854, being promoted <a href="major-general">major-general</a> on 20 June 1854. Due to a severe attack of fever in July, he was forced to return home as the army embarked for the <a href="Crimea">Crimea</a>. He was promoted <a href="lieutenant-general">lieutenant-general</a> on 12 March 1861, appointed colonel of the <a href="4th%20Queen%27s%20Own%20Hussars">4th (Queen's Own) Hussars</a> on 6 February 1865, and promoted <a href="general">general</a> on 10 November 1868.
Political career.
In February 1852 Lord de Ros was appointed <a href="Captain%20of%20the%20Yeomen%20of%20the%20Guard">Captain of the Yeomen of the Guard</a> in the <a href="Edward%20Smith-Stanley%2C%2014th%20Earl%20of%20Derby">Earl of Derby</a>'s <a href="Conservative%20Government%201852">first administration</a>, and sworn of the <a href="Her%20Majesty%27s%20Most%20Honourable%20Privy%20Council">Privy Council</a>. The government fell in December 1852, but when Derby returned to office in February 1858, de Ros was once again made Captain of the Yeomen of the Guard. He continued in this post until Derby resigned in June 1859.
Family.
Lord de Ros married his second cousin Lady Georgiana Lennox (<a href="Molecombe">Molecombe</a>, <a href="Sussex">Sussex</a>, 30 September 1795 – <a href="London">London</a>, 15 December 1891), daughter of <a href="Charles%20Lennox%2C%204th%20Duke%20of%20Richmond">Charles Lennox, 4th Duke of Richmond</a>, his father's first cousin, in <a href="London">London</a> on 7 June 1824. They had three children:
Lord de Ros died at Old Court, <a href="Strangford">Strangford</a>, <a href="County%20Down">County Down</a>, in January 1874, aged 76, and was succeeded in the barony by his only son, Dudley. Lady de Ros died in <a href="London">London</a> in December 1891, aged 96.
